{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3020774,"name":"Ella","username":"El21","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/e/a4c791/{size}.png","created_at":"2022-03-10T21:09:30.078Z","cooked":"

So we just got these IR Beam Break Sensors from Ada Fruit and are now trying to hook them up in the DIO. Does anyone know how to connect them into the DIO of the Rio and how to bring power to the light part of these sensors?

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2022-03-10T21:09:30.078Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1001,"reads":243,"readers_count":242,"score":5033.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":405318,"topic_slug":"wiring-help-with-ada-fruit-ir-beam-break-sensors-in-dio","display_username":"Ella","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://learn.adafruit.com/ir-breakbeam-sensors/arduino","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Arduino | IR Breakbeam Sensors | Adafruit Learning System","clicks":93}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":48863,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/wiring-help-with-ada-fruit-ir-beam-break-sensors-in-dio/405318/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3020789,"name":"James","username":"otherguy","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/otherguy/{size}/180121_2.png","created_at":"2022-03-10T21:24:08.569Z","cooked":"

The emitter (one with two conductors) needs to be wired to a 3v or 5v source.
You could steal 5v off the Rio or VRM (if you have one).

The detector side should wire to a DIO port on the Rio.

  • Red to 5v
  • Black to gnd
  • Yellow to signal

Treat code like a normal discrete input.

FIRST Robotics Competition Documentation

Digital Inputs - Software

The roboRIO’s FPGA supports up to 26 digital inputs. 10 of these are made available through the built-in DIO ports on the RIO itself, while the other 16 are available through the MXP breakout port....

Note you’ll indicate a true value (logic high) when the detector side CANNOT see the Emitter (beam is broken). There is an internal pull-up resistor on the discrete input channels within the roborio.

Some info on the DIO ports of the Rio is here:

FIRST Robotics Competition Documentation

Digital Inputs - Hardware

A digital signal is a signal that can be in one of several discrete states. In the vast majority of cases, the signal is the voltage in a wire, and there are only two states for a digital signal - ...

You should be able to pull +5V from another DIO (or even from the same one). You have to watch the total current draw from all these ports on the RIO, but should be fine if you just have one or two of these sensors.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2022-03-11T01:39:33.126Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":21,"reads":187,"readers_count":186,"score":157.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":405318,"topic_slug":"wiring-help-with-ada-fruit-ir-beam-break-sensors-in-dio","display_username":"Allen Nuttle","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":14283,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/wiring-help-with-ada-fruit-ir-beam-break-sensors-in-dio/405318/3","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3021016,"name":"Brian Scharles Jr","username":"bscharles","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bscharles/{size}/139113_2.png","created_at":"2022-03-11T04:06:02.302Z","cooked":"

A word of warning, we had these on our robot last week at the Northern Lights regional. They worked great for us in our shop for weeks, but when we got to competition, they became a nightmare. They would detect fine in the pit, then we’d go out to the field, and suddenly wouldn’t trigger. After spending all of Thursday and Friday troubleshooting, I found a note here about venue lights giving off IR, so I glued plastic standoffs to the receivers to shroud them; finally they worked better (but still not perfect).

After this experience, we’ve since decided to ditch the IR and replace them with these CAN Time of Flight sensors. We heard good things about them and should have them hopefully tomorrow to integrate. Moral of the story, a good, reliable sensor is worth the added cost.

bscharles:

ditch the IR

Would you expect the Rev 2M Distance sensor to have the same problem? 2m Distance Sensor - REV Robotics

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2022-03-11T05:52:32.728Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":6,"reads":156,"readers_count":155,"score":66.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":405318,"topic_slug":"wiring-help-with-ada-fruit-ir-beam-break-sensors-in-dio","display_username":"Owen Busler","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.revrobotics.com/rev-31-1505/","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"2m Distance Sensor - REV Robotics","clicks":21}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":23320,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/wiring-help-with-ada-fruit-ir-beam-break-sensors-in-dio/405318/5","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3021055,"name":"","username":"apm4242","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/apm4242/{size}/68369_2.png","created_at":"2022-03-11T06:04:47.851Z","cooked":"

We use a PWM wire (included in the KOP). Cut the male end off and separate the red, black, and white wires. Take the red wire from the PWM wire and solder it to the red wire from the transmitting side and the red wire from the receiving side (make a Y). Do the same with the black wires (make a Y). Solder the remaining white wires together.

Plug the female PWM cable into one of the DIO ports. Check the diagram on the rio to see which way to plug it in (black is ground).

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2022-03-11T06:04:47.851Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":6,"reads":150,"readers_count":149,"score":75.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":405318,"topic_slug":"wiring-help-with-ada-fruit-ir-beam-break-sensors-in-dio","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":20007,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/wiring-help-with-ada-fruit-ir-beam-break-sensors-in-dio/405318/6","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3021058,"name":"Ryan Blue","username":"Ryan_Blue","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/ryan_blue/{size}/174016_2.png","created_at":"2022-03-11T06:10:17.973Z","cooked":"

The PWF tof sensor and the REV sensor both use the same underlying technology (940nm class 1 IR laser). However, I would be more inclined to use the CAN connected sensor due to the issues with the I2C bus on the roborio.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2022-03-11T06:10:52.898Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":140,"readers_count":139,"score":43.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":405318,"topic_slug":"wiring-help-with-ada-fruit-ir-beam-break-sensors-in-dio","display_username":"Ryan Blue","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/reliability-of-onboard-i2c-port-for-2022/399394","internal":true,"reflection":false,"title":"Reliability of Onboard I2C port for 2022","clicks":10}],"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":23320,"username":"Owen_Busler","name":"Owen Busler","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/owen_busler/{size}/7684_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":29846,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"WPILib Dev | 1024 Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/wiring-help-with-ada-fruit-ir-beam-break-sensors-in-dio/405318/7","custom_user_title":"WPILib Dev | 1024 Mentor","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3021122,"name":"Brian Scharles Jr","username":"bscharles","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bscharles/{size}/139113_2.png","created_at":"2022-03-11T13:18:01.569Z","cooked":"

Agreed, they have nearly identical STM32 ToF chips (the Rev senses up to 2M, the PWF senses up to 4M). But as mentioned, the PWF CAN interface will totally avoid the roboRIO I2C issues this year (and may clean up your wiring more if you have multiple sensors on your robot). If you do have the Rev sensor (or the I2C version of the PWF sensor), just make sure to use the MXP I2C port as mentioned in the link above.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2022-03-11T13:18:01.569Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":124,"readers_count":123,"score":54.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":405318,"topic_slug":"wiring-help-with-ada-fruit-ir-beam-break-sensors-in-dio","display_username":"Brian Scharles Jr","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":29846,"username":"Ryan_Blue","name":"Ryan Blue","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/ryan_blue/{size}/174016_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":13665,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/wiring-help-with-ada-fruit-ir-beam-break-sensors-in-dio/405318/8","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3021131,"name":"Andy Mundell","username":"suPURDUEperAndy","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/supurdueperandy/{size}/266209_2.png","created_at":"2022-03-11T13:25:55.919Z","cooked":"

We’ve used these for 2 years in our indexers with no problems. Perhaps it has to do with the location and their likelihood of coming in contact with peripheral light. Definitely test them, and do it in a variety of lighting, but our experience has been good.

A shroud sounds like a good idea. We have typically drilled a hole in 0.25" polycarb and glued them to the other side, so we have a natural 0.25" deep shroud around the receiver.

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2022-03-11T13:27:59.906Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":119,"readers_count":118,"score":63.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":405318,"topic_slug":"wiring-help-with-ada-fruit-ir-beam-break-sensors-in-dio","display_username":"Andy Mundell","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":13665,"username":"bscharles","name":"Brian Scharles Jr","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bscharles/{size}/139113_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":36711,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"7457 Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/wiring-help-with-ada-fruit-ir-beam-break-sensors-in-dio/405318/9","custom_user_title":"7457 Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3021135,"name":"Ryan Blue","username":"Ryan_Blue","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/ryan_blue/{size}/174016_2.png","created_at":"2022-03-11T13:41:43.526Z","cooked":"
bscharles:

just make sure to use the MXP I2C port as mentioned in the link above.

The MXP I2C lines also appear to have issues, as discussed later in that thread. The best solution seems to be a coprocessor such as a raspberry pi or pi pico that handles the I2C transactions and reports data back via serial/NT/dio.
